InformationProduct.Abstract: Fecundity of fish is influenced by several factors, including body length, condition, population density, and environmental conditions. It follows that fecundity of fish populations can exhibit spatiotemporal variability; thus, periodic quantification of length–fecundity relationships is important for management. We hypothesized that average fecundity of Cisco Coregonus artedi in the upper Laurentian Great Lakes would be lower in Lake Superior than in Lakes Huron and Michigan. The trophic status of these lakes recently converged, but Lakes Huron and Michigan currently support lower Cisco densities; thus, we expected that they would reach larger sizes and have greater fecundity owing to lower intraspecific competition. Ovaries were collected from prespawn Cisco during 2008–2010 to test this hypothesis. We also compared length–fecundity relationships for 2008–2010 to those of precollapse (1930s–1950s) populations to explore how relationships have changed. Average fecundity of Cisco during 2008–2010 was lower in Lake Superior compared to Lakes Huron and Michigan; length–fecundity relationships in the latter two lakes did not vary significantly, so they were combined. Body condition was highest in Lakes Huron and Michigan. We used otoliths to determine age and found that body condition was domed shaped with respect to age in Lakes Huron and Superior. There were no females older than age 5 in our samples from Lake Michigan because that population was just beginning to recover from very low levels. Females of intermediate age had the highest fecundities in both Lake Huron (ages 7–13) and Lake Superior (ages 8–18). We hypothesize that differences in body morphometry may also influence fecundity, with deeper-bodied C. artedi albus, the predominant form in Lakes Michigan and Huron, having greater fecundity than shallower-bodied C. artedi artedi in Lake Superior. Moreover, varying Cisco diets and seasonal movement patterns across lakes may have also contributed to differences. Females in Lakes Superior and Michigan are currently more fecund than their precollapse counterparts.
InformationProduct.Cooperators: Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources; U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service; The Fresh Lake Whitefish Company; and the Michigan Department of Natural Resources.
InformationProduct.FinalTitle: Does Fecundity of Cisco Vary in the Upper Great Lakes?
InformationProduct.JournalTitle: North American Journal of Fisheries Management
InformationProduct.WorkingTitle: Does Fecundity of Cisco Vary in the Upper Great Lakes?
InformationProduct.ProductSummary: Fecundity of fish is influenced by several factors, including body length, condition, population density, and environmental conditions. It follows that fecundity of fish populations can exhibit spatiotemporal variability; thus, periodic quantification of length–fecundity relationships is important for management. We hypothesized that average fecundity of Cisco Coregonus artedi in the upper Laurentian Great Lakes would be lower in Lake Superior than in Lakes Huron and Michigan. The trophic status of these lakes recently converged, but Lakes Huron and Michigan currently support lower Cisco densities; thus, we expected that they would reach larger sizes and have greater fecundity owing to lower intraspecific competition. Ovaries were collected from prespawn Cisco during 2008–2010 to test this hypothesis. We also compared length–fecundity relationships for 2008–2010 to those of precollapse (1930s–1950s) populations to explore how relationships have changed. Average fecundity of Cisco during 2008–2010 was lower in Lake Superior compared to Lakes Huron and Michigan; length–fecundity relationships in the latter two lakes did not vary significantly, so they were combined. Body condition was highest in Lakes Huron and Michigan. We used otoliths to determine age and found that body condition was domed shaped with respect to age in Lakes Huron and Superior. There were no females older than age 5 in our samples from Lake Michigan because that population was just beginning to recover from very low levels. Females of intermediate age had the highest fecundities in both Lake Huron (ages 7–13) and Lake Superior (ages 8–18). Moreover, varying Cisco diets and seasonal movement patterns across lakes may have also contributed to differences. Females in Lakes Superior and Michigan are currently more fecund than their precollapse counterparts.

Reviewer.ReviewerAffiliation: U.S. Geological Survey - Great Lakes Science Center

Task.Comments:
Mark,
I got a bill for page charges that Leah is taking care of for me. I consider this matter closed.
Dan

Please see file added to IPDS with comments from BAO for author. After addressing BAO comments, manuscript has Bureau Approval (11Nov19). Thank you for your help with the USGS FSP review and approval process.

Kurt,
I'm forwarding a manuscript where I solicited two USGS reviews (Jean Adams and Jason Stockwell) and have reconciled those reviews. I've loaded up their reviews into IPDS, the rewrite and a document that describes how concerns and questions were addressed. So I'm now seeking Bureau Approval. I have not submitted the manuscript to the North American Journal of Fisheries Management yet and will wait for Bureau Approval to do so. It is my understanding that I'm to circle back to you after rewriting the paper after peer review to see if it will need a second round of Bureau Approval.
Dan

Mark,
I would like to have Jean Adams and Jason Stockwell provide the USGS-solicited reviews. This version has a couple of items in track changes from one of my coauthors (Mark Ebener) that I still need to address, but they are largely cosmetic so I decided to move forward. I will need help from another coauthor to make the changes Mark is suggesting because she built the figures for me using R. Jean said she could review this for me on July 19th, but you probably won't see this request until you get back into internet coverage on 22 July. So I'm jumping the gun, but I could wait a few weeks to get back on Jean's radar if I miss this opportunity.
Dan
